mainQuiz.title: Ancient Encryption Fundamentals
mainQuiz.description: Test your knowledge of historical encryption methods and their significance

questions.question: Which civilization is credited with inventing the scytale, one of the first military encryption devices?
questions.explanation: The Spartans invented the scytale in the 5th century BCE for military communications. It consisted of a cylinder with a strip of parchment wrapped around it.

questions.question: What is the key characteristic of a monoalphabetic substitution cipher?
options: Each letter is consistently replaced by the same substitute
Multiple alphabets are used for encryption
questions.explanation: In a monoalphabetic substitution cipher, each letter in the plaintext is consistently replaced by the same letter in the ciphertext.

questions.question: The Vigenère cipher improved upon simpler ciphers by:
questions.explanation: The Vigenère cipher used a keyword to create multiple shift values, making it much harder to crack than single-shift ciphers.

questions.question: What made the Pigpen cipher unique?
options: It used symbols instead of letters
It needed two people to operate
questions.explanation: The Pigpen (or masonic) cipher replaced letters with symbolic representations based on their position in a grid, making it visually distinct from other methods.

questions.question: Which historical figure is famous for breaking the Vigenère cipher?
questions.explanation: Charles Babbage broke the Vigenère cipher in the 19th century, though his discovery wasn't published until years later.
